investor_info.name: Howard Marks
investor_info.title: Co-Chairman & Co-Founder, Oaktree Capital Management
investor_info.investment_philosophy: Risk-controlled value investing with focus on market cycles, contrarian thinking, and buying when others are fearful
famous_quotes: You can't predict. You can prepare.
The biggest investing errors come from psychology, not analysis.
There's nothing new in investing. There are only old mistakes made by new people.

insights.content: The oak tree of investment philosophy is simple: buy low, sell high. But most people do the opposite because of psychological forces. That's why few succeed.
insights.source: Oaktree Memo - The Most Important Thing
insights.context: Explaining the fundamental challenge in investing

insights.content: When everyone's bullish and prices are high, that's when you should be cautious. When there's blood in the streets and everyone's pessimistic, that's opportunity time.
insights.context: Advising on market positioning based on sentiment

insights.content: High yield bonds are offering incredible value now. Spreads are wide, defaults are manageable, and you're getting paid well for taking reasonable risk.
insights.context: Discussing opportunities in distressed debt markets

insights.content: Real estate is cyclical, but great properties in great locations are always valuable. The key is buying during downturns when cap rates are attractive.
Technology stocks are priced for perfection. That doesn't mean they're bad businesses, but the risk/reward is unattractive. I prefer cheaper alternatives.
Private credit is where the opportunities are today. Banks have retreated from middle market lending, creating attractive risk-adjusted returns for private lenders.
insights.context: Highlighting opportunities in private credit markets

insights.content: Emerging markets are hated, which makes them interesting. You have to separate the good countries from the bad, but valuations are compelling.
Energy transition creates opportunities and risks. Traditional energy is cheap but declining. Renewable is growing but expensive. There's opportunity in both.
insights.context: Analyzing investment implications of energy transition

notable_memo_themes: The Importance of Having a Philosophy
